This song is thought to be about how John Lennon felt about his then-wife, Cynthia, when it came out in 1965. The song reads like he is talking to Cynthia or maybe writing her a letter, reflecting on their relationship. According to the Beatles Bible website, the Lennons were also experimenting with LSD at this time, which makes this opening line all the more fitting.

Drug use, however, later became a contributing factor to their divorce as well as his infidelity, according to Cynthia.

Years later, in an actual letter sent to Cynthia, John stated their marriage was over long before psychedelics or Yoko Ono came along. The letter, written in 1976, went up for auction in 2017:

Is it right that you and I should fight
 Every night?
 Just the sight of you makes nighttime bright
 Very bright
 Haven’t I the right to make it up, girl?

In his book Revolution In The Head, Ian MacDonald explained how Lennon’s melodies tended to be ‘horizontal’ in nature, often based around a single repeated note, whereas McCartney’s would climb up and down the scales ‘vertically’.



It’s Only Love, however, is more melodically ‘vertical’ than many of Lennon’s compositions of the time. If Lennon was later ashamed by the lyrics, the winding tune and explorative chord sequence showed that he wasn’t simply going through the motions of songwriting.

Even though Lennon wrote this song, he did not like the lyrics. Some of this lyrics describe his affection for Cynthia Lennon and how he felt about the situation he was living. Lennon knew how he loved her, and since all the fame was coming in his way he found it hard to love and spend time for her, but fame was being a huge problem blocking their love.
